solution_line_template: In the trucks, James saw {num_trucks} * {people_per_truck} = <<{num_trucks}*{people_per_truck}={people_in_trucks}>>{people_in_trucks} people.
In the buses, he saw {num_buses} * {people_per_bus} = <<{num_buses}*{people_per_bus}={people_in_buses}>>{people_in_buses} people.
He saw {multiplier_for_taxis} * {num_buses} = <<{multiplier_for_taxis}*{num_buses}={num_taxis}>>{num_taxis} taxis go past him.
Therefore, he saw {num_taxis} * {people_per_taxi} = <<{num_taxis}*{people_per_taxi}={people_in_taxis}>>{people_in_taxis} people in the taxis.
In the cars, he saw {num_cars} * {people_per_car} = <<{num_cars}*{people_per_car}={people_in_cars}>>{people_in_cars} people.

Since we know how many vehicles James saw in total, we know that he saw {total_vehicles_counted} - {num_trucks} - {num_buses} - {num_taxis} - {num_cars} = <<{total_vehicles_counted}-{num_trucks}-{num_buses}-{num_taxis}-{num_cars}={num_motorbikes}>>{num_motorbikes} motorbikes.
So, he saw {num_motorbikes} * {people_per_motorbike} = <<{num_motorbikes}*{people_per_motorbike}={people_on_motorbikes}>>{people_on_motorbikes} people on motorbikes.

He has therefore seen a total of {people_in_trucks} + {people_in_buses} + {people_in_taxis} + {people_in_cars} + {people_on_motorbikes} = <<{people_in_trucks}+{people_in_buses}+{people_in_taxis}+{people_in_cars}+{people_on_motorbikes}={total_passengers}>>{total_passengers} people.
